p: Analytical tools, including high-performance liquid chromatography (HPLC) or liquid chromatography/mass spectrometry (LC/MS), coupled with chemometric analyses (i.e., principal component analysis, hierarchical clustering analysis, and discriminant analysis) have been recognized as comprehensive and useful techniques for the discrimination of geographical plants origins, chemotaxonomic authentication of botanical species, and quality evaluations of herbal medicines [ 17, 18, 19]. These tools also make it possible to differentiate the chemical characteristics of plants by parts, by identifying the phytochemicals strongly associated with such differentiations [ 20, 21, 22]. Thus, it is highly applicable to investigate the organ-specific phytochemicals in medicinal plants with two more therapeutic parts that are readily available, as is the case with M. alba.
